title: NIS-2
description:
The NIS-2 Directive, officially known as Directive (EU) 2022/2555, aims to establish a high common level of cybersecurity across the European Union by enhancing the existing legal framework on network and information systems security. 

The directive mandates that Member States adopt national cybersecurity strategies, establish designated authorities, and develop incident response teams (CSIRTs). It emphasizes the importance of risk management measures, incident reporting, and information sharing both within Member States and across the EU. To support these efforts, the directive outlines structured cooperation frameworks, including the establishment of a Cooperation Group and networks for CSIRTs and other operational entities to enhance coordination and response to cyber threats and incidents.

 The NIS-2 Directive emphasizes placing cybersecurity at the core of organizational strategies across the EU, requiring entities to integrate robust technical and organizational measures. While certain aspects like monitoring infrastructures can be automated, the directive extensively covers processes and communication that must be managed at the organizational level. These include developing governance frameworks, training staff, and enhancing incident response capabilities, underscoring that effective cybersecurity is not just about technology but also about cultivating a culture of security awareness and responsiveness that automation alone cannot achieve.

children.title: Article 1: Subject Matter
children.description: Defines the directive's objective to achieve a high common level of cybersecurity across the Union, amending certain regulations and repealing the NIS Directive.

children.title: Article 2: Scope
children.description: Outlines the entities and services covered by the directive, focusing on essential and important entities that provide critical services.

children.title: Article 3: Essential and important entities
children.description: Specifies criteria for identifying essential and important entities, focusing on their critical role in society and the economy.

children.title: Article 4: Sector-specific Union legal acts
children.description: Addresses the relationship between this directive and other sector-specific EU legislation concerning cybersecurity obligations.

children.title: Article 5: Minimum harmonisation
children.description: Clarifies that the directive sets minimum standards, allowing Member States to maintain or introduce more stringent measures.

children.title: Article 6: Definitions
children.description: Provides definitions for terms used within the directive to ensure clarity and uniform understanding across the Union.

children.title: Article 7: National cybersecurity strategy
children.description: Requires Member States to develop national cybersecurity strategies that include strategic objectives and governance frameworks to achieve them.

children.title: Article 8: Competent authorities and single points of contact
children.description: Mandates Member States to designate competent authorities and a single point of contact to ensure cross-border cooperation on cybersecurity.

children.title: Article 9: National cyber crisis management frameworks
children.description: Calls for Member States to establish frameworks for managing national cyber crises, including preparedness and response measures.

children.title: Article 10: Computer security incident response teams (CSIRTs)
children.description: Outlines the establishment, operation, and tasks of national CSIRTs to respond to cybersecurity incidents.

children.title: Article 11: Requirements, technical capabilities and tasks of CSIRTs
children.description: Details the capabilities and responsibilities of CSIRTs, including monitoring, reporting, and responding to cybersecurity incidents.

children.title: Article 12: Coordinated vulnerability disclosure and a European vulnerability database
children.description: Introduces a framework for coordinated vulnerability disclosure and the creation of a European vulnerability database to enhance cybersecurity.

children.title: Article 13: Cooperation at national level
children.description: Promotes cooperation among national authorities, CSIRTs, and other stakeholders to strengthen national cybersecurity frameworks.

children.title: CHAPTER III: COOPERATION AT UNION AND INTERNATIONAL LEVEL
Article 14: Cooperation Group
children.description: Establishes a Cooperation Group to facilitate strategic cooperation on cybersecurity across Member States and sectors.

children.title: Article 15: CSIRTs network
children.description: Forms a network of national CSIRTs to enhance operational cooperation across the Union on incident response.

children.title: Article 16: European cyber crisis liaison organisation network (EU-CyCLONe)
children.description: Sets up EU-CyCLONe to coordinate responses to large-scale cross-border cybersecurity incidents and crises.

children.title: Article 17: International Cooperation
children.description: Encourages cooperation with third countries and international organizations to improve global cybersecurity practices and resilience.

children.title: Article 18: Report on the state of cybersecurity in the Union
children.description: Mandates a biennial report by ENISA on the state of cybersecurity in the Union, assessing risks, capabilities, and compliance.

children.title: Article 19: Peer reviews
children.description: Introduces a peer review mechanism among Member States to enhance mutual trust and cybersecurity capabilities through shared learning.

children.title: CHAPTER IV: CYBERSECURITY RISK-MANAGEMENT MEASURES AND REPORTING OBLIGATIONS
Article 20: Governance
children.description: Requires entities to have governance policies addressing cybersecurity risk management and incident reporting.

children.title: Article 21: Cybersecurity risk-management measures
children.description: Defines specific technical and organizational measures that entities must implement to manage cybersecurity risks.

children.title: Article 22: Union level coordinated security risk assessments of critical supply chains
children.description: Calls for coordinated security risk assessments at the Union level to address cybersecurity risks in critical supply chains.

children.title: Article 23: Reporting obligations
children.description: Details reporting obligations for incidents, providing timelines and procedures for notifying national authorities.

children.title: Article 24: Use of European cybersecurity certification schemes
children.description: Encourages the use of EU cybersecurity certification schemes to demonstrate compliance with cybersecurity requirements.

children.title: Article 25: Standardisation
children.description: Promotes the development and use of standardised practices and tools to enhance cybersecurity across the Union.

children.title: Article 26: Jurisdiction and territoriality
children.description: Defines the jurisdictional scope of the directive, clarifying where and how it applies to entities operating within the Union.

children.title: Article 27: Registry of entities
children.description: Requires the creation of a registry for entities falling under the scope of the directive to facilitate oversight and compliance.

children.title: Article 28: Database of domain name registration data
children.description: Mandates the establishment of a database containing registration data for domain names to support cybersecurity measures.

children.title: Article 29: Cybersecurity information-sharing arrangements
children.description: Outlines the establishment of information-sharing arrangements to enhance the collective cybersecurity posture.

children.title: Article 30: Voluntary notification of relevant information
children.description: Allows for and regulates the voluntary sharing of information about cybersecurity threats and incidents among stakeholders.

children.title: Article 31: General aspects concerning supervision and enforcement
children.description: Provides an overview of the supervisory and enforcement framework established by the directive for monitoring compliance.

children.title: Article 32: Supervisory and enforcement measures in relation to essential entities
children.description: Details the supervisory and enforcement measures that apply specifically to essential entities under the directive.

children.title: Article 33: Supervisory and enforcement measures in relation to important entities
children.description: Details the supervisory and enforcement measures that apply specifically to important entities under the directive.

children.title: Article 34: General conditions for imposing administrative fines on essential and important entities
children.description: Specifies conditions under which administrative fines may be imposed on entities for non-compliance with the directive.

children.title: Article 35: Infringements entailing a personal data breach
children.description: Addresses the specific obligations and penalties associated with cybersecurity incidents that involve personal data breaches.

children.title: Article 36: Penalties
children.description: Defines the penalties for non-compliance with the directive, aiming to ensure adherence to cybersecurity practices.

children.title: Article 37: Mutual assistance
children.description: Promotes mutual assistance among Member States in the enforcement of the directive, enhancing cooperative cybersecurity efforts.

children.title: CHAPTER VIII: DELEGATED AND IMPLEMENTING ACTS
Article 38: Exercise of the delegation
children.description: Describes the conditions under which the European Commission is delegated powers to adopt certain acts under the directive.

children.title: Article 39: Committee procedure
children.description: Outlines the procedural rules for the committee that assists the European Commission in exercising its delegated powers.

children.title: Article 40: Review
children.description: Mandates regular reviews of the directive's effectiveness and the adequacy of its measures, potentially leading to amendments.

children.title: Article 41: Transposition
children.description: Sets deadlines for Member States to transpose the directive into national law and to begin applying its measures.

children.title: Article 42: Amendment of Regulation (EU) No 910/2014
children.description: Details amendments to existing regulations to align with the new directive's provisions.

children.title: Article 43: Amendment of Directive (EU) 2018/1972
children.description: Details amendments to existing directives to align with the new directive's provisions.

children.title: Article 44: Repeal
children.description: Notes the repeal of the previous NIS Directive, replaced by this more comprehensive directive.

children.title: Article 45: Entry into force
children.description: Specifies when the directive comes into effect, starting the timeline for compliance by Member States and relevant entities.

children.title: Article 46: Addressees
children.description: Clarifies that the directive is addressed to Member States, which are responsible for its implementation and enforcement.
